Dear Mr. Roach:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violation report why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
Facility has been out of ratio in the afternoon and evening, with a unit having one
staff to supervise 8 youth. This leaves youth in danger.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 07/19/21 from the DCWL online complaint website.
The anonymous complainant left no contact information. The information in the
complaint is as follows. During the afternoon and evening the campus was working
out of ratio, sometimes with a unit only having one staff with 8 kids. This left kids and
staff in danger. Multiple units were out of ratio. This reportedly occurred on Sunday,
July 18th from 12:30pm onwards through the day. This reportedly occurred at the
following cottages: Junkhe, Cotcher, Harrison and Burnham and the staff and
supervisors are aware. The complainant further noted, ‘During a phone call with my
child staff said that there were not enough staff around campus to accommodate
phone calls or for the kids to go outside. My kid also told me that staff were coming
in and out and that they never have staff on the weekends. Dinner was being
prepared late and at one point that staff on the phone said they were by themselves
with 10 kids.’
On 07/19/21, Consultant 2 forwarded an email from Administrator 2 regarding
staffing. Administrator 2 emailed, ‘We have not had issues with maintaining ratio with
the exception of occasional calls offs which are then covered by supervisors if
contingents cannot be found to cover.’
I met with Administrators 1 and 2 at the facility on 07/20/21 and advised them of the
allegations. Documentation was requested. Administrator 1 acknowledged that they
are tight with staffing but was not sure if they had been out of ratio on 07/18/21.
I spoke with Consultant 2 on 08/09/21 and she reported having been onsite with
Consultant 3 on 08/06/21. During their onsite, a supervisor was crying and feeling
panicked about the lack of staffing. Safety planning was established with
Administrator 2 and consisted of the facility not taking new placements until staffing
can be stabilized and for therapists and case managers to cover shifts if needed.
Consultant 3 emailed with the following information related to her 08/06/21 onsite
visit, ‘I had interviewed a Residential Supervisor, and Youth Specialist 2 and they
both reported they are short staffed and are always out of ratio. They didn’t provide
specific dates but did say it’s usually second shift.’
On 08/11/21, I interviewed Youth Specialist 1 via phone. Youth Specialist 1 reported
that the previous weekend, they were the only staff with 11 kids in the Cotcher
cottage. There was a supervisor reported to be there also. Youth Specialist 1
working 12-hour days and reported the “staffing is getting worse.”
3

On 08/11/21, I exchanged emails with Administrators 1 and 2 to advise of the likely
licensing violations for this investigation. Administrator 2 confirmed the following
related to staffing in an email, ‘I actually informed Consultants 2 and 3 that we have
a freeze on admissions which has been communicated with RPU and our
admissions department. In addition, case managers and therapist are on an
afternoon rotation where they will be covering any vacancies.’
Documentation reviewed for this investigation is as follows, with applicable
information outlined:
 Staff schedules provided by Administrator 1, for the identified cottages, were
reviewed for July 18th. Administrator 1 also provided a census for each
cottage for that date as well. It was observed from the information provided
that the facility was not in compliance with staffing ratios as two of the
cottages were short staffed per their ratio.
 Facility policy, Section F. Number 3. Child Supervision: 2. MCHS schedules
staff to maintain a 4:1 ratio. Staff should strive to maintain this ratio, though
there will be times when staff cannot, such as when a child goes AWOL, or
during a restraint. This does not mean that staff are out of ratio because there
are ample staff scheduled to respond to the child issues.
 MDHHS RFCAN Contract:
Staffing Ratio, The Contractor shall:
a. Provide a minimum of one on-duty direct care worker for every 4
children during waking hours.
b. Maintain a minimum of one on-duty direct care worker for every 10
children during sleeping hours. All of these staff shall be awake during this
period. Room checks must be conducted at variable intervals of no more
than every 15 minutes between checks during sleeping hours.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as they were confirmed to
have been out of ratio compliance on 07/18/21 based on the
documentation they provided. Additionally, it has been reported
by staff and acknowledged by the administrators that they are
not always able to meet ratio on other days and in various
cottages.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Cited under the contract
SIR 2021C0108045; CAP pending
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
